content: P.L. 106-554, signed in December 2000, enacted H.R. 5658 for Treasury and General Government Appropriations in 2001. Funding was provided for various accounts, including the General Services Administration and Executive Residence. P.L. 106-346 (H.R. 4475) partially funded select accounts from the primary funding measure. Prior to enactment of P.L. 106-554, there were several measures that either would have or did fund affected accounts, including House bill H.R. 4871, Senate bill S. 2900, Legislative Branch Appropriation H.R. 4516/H.R. 4985, Transportation Appropriations P.L. 106-346 (H.R. 4475), and FY2001 Continuing Funding Resolution P.L. 106-275. The Act P.L. 106-554 (H.R. 5658) funds accounts within the Treasury, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and General Government for FY2001. P.L. 106-346 provides supplemental funding for certain accounts. The President submits the Budget of the United States Government annually to Congress. Congress passes a concurrent resolution establishing the congressional budget and setting budgetary levels for future years. The congressional budget is established through a concurrent resolution, with discretionary funding levels allocated to subcommittees. Treasury appropriations fund law enforcement organizations like the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms, Customs Service, and Secret Service. Additionally, they cover agencies like the Internal Revenue Service and the Bureau of the Public Debt. The Federal Law Enforcement Training Center, Treasury appropriations cover various agencies including the Internal Revenue Service, Financial Management Service, and Bureau of the Public Debt. The U.S. Postal Service is mostly self-supporting, with limited federal contributions for specific purposes like free postal service for the blind. Appropriations for the Executive Office of the President fund salaries, expenses, and operations of various agencies within the EOP, such as the Council of Economic Advisers and the Office of Management and Budget. Funding for drug control initiatives is allocated by the Office of National Drug Control Policy. The Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP) distributes funding for drug control initiatives to various entities, including independent agencies like the Federal Election Commission and the National Archives. The Treasury and General Government appropriation includes titles that set governmentwide restrictions and authorize specific actions. For example, there are provisions prohibiting the use of funds for employing non-U.S. citizens. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2001, P.L. 106-554, includes provisions such as a .22% across-the-board rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligations funds. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) is required to report on the implementation. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2001 includes a .22% across-the-board rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligations funds. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) must report on the implementation, affecting all accounts in the Treasury and General Government appropriations. The rescission applies to various appropriations, including advance appropriations for FY 2001 and discretionary emergency appropriations. The reduction must be applied equally to each program, project, and activity subject to the rescission. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2001 includes a .22% across-the-board rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligations funds. Agencies must allocate the reduction on a pro-rata basis to every program, project, and activity subject to the rescission without exception. The FY2000 Consolidated Appropriations Act mandated a 0.38% across-the-board rescission of discretionary budget authority. OMB specified reductions in department accounts, allowing flexibility to protect high-priority programs as long as the overall reduction target was met. The FY2000 Consolidated Appropriations Act mandated a 0.38% across-the-board rescission of discretionary budget authority, allowing flexibility to protect high-priority programs within each department. The FY2001 rescission provisions exempt certain programs and are universally applied. The FY2001 Military Construction Appropriations Act includes funding provisions affecting accounts covered by the Treasury/Postal Service measure. The term "net" in this report refers to FY2000 appropriated levels reduced by the rescinded amount.
